captions.text:
[ Chuckles ] People always call
a madhouse ''some place,'' don't they ?
Put her in ''some place.''

l'm sorry. l didn't mean it
to sound uncaring.

What do you know
about caring ?

Have you ever seen the inside
of one of those places ?
The laughing and the tears...

and the cruel eyes
studying you.
My mother there ?

[ Chuckles ]
But she's harmless.

She's as harmless as one
of those stuffed birds.
l am sorry.

l only felt--
It seems she's hurting you.

- l meant well.
- People always mean well.

They cluck their thick tongues
and shake their heads and suggest--
oh, so very delicately--

Of course,
l've suggested it myself.

But l hate to even think about it.
She needs me.

lt-- It's not as if she were
a-- a maniac, a raving thing.
She--

She iust goes
a little mad sometimes.

We all go a little mad
sometimes.

[ Chuckles ]
Haven't you ?
Yes.

Sometimes iust one time
can be enough. Thank you.
Norman.

Oh, you're not-- you're not
going back to your room already ?

[ Sighs ]
l'm very tired.

And l have a long drive tomorrow,
all the way back to Phoenix.

title: We All Go a Little Mad Sometimes - Psycho (3/12) Movie CLIP (1960) HD

comments.author: Xehanort10

comments.text:
+Abraham Lincoln I know, it's great. Hitchcock tried to trick audiences 
into believing the movie was about Janet Leigh's character because she was 
a huge star at the time. When I first saw the movie, I assumed the title 
*Psycho* was an exaggerated reference to Marion Crane temporarily going a 
little crazy when she makes the decision to steal the $40,000. 


I thought the movie would be some kind of chase/crime drama about a woman 
falling further into darkness while at the same time trying to regain her 
sanity after committing a crime that's eating away at her conscience. 


I thought the bit with Norman Bates at the motel was a tiny subplot that 
would end quickly. It wasn't until I heard Mother's voice that I knew 
something else was going on here. Then after Crane was murdered, the focus 
shifted and it was slowly revealed that the story was not about her, it's 
about *him*. Great movie.
comments.author: BTTFMovie

comments.text: Pretty risky move, but that's Hitchcock for ya. lol.

comments.author: Chimmeechimmeecocoapuffs

comments.text:
Tonight's fright flick...Psycho (1960), which I've been viewing at least 
annually for more than 30 years. Not much left to be said about this 
picture that hasn't been recounted before. Well, if you've seen it as many 
times as I have, you may appreciate the fact that much of the film is very 
dark comedy:

"Mother - how shall I say? -- isn't herself today."

Or we could talk about how Marion Crane's last name links thematically with 
the stuffed birds in the office and parlor of the Bates Motel.

Or that this film is the first in cinema history to show the flushing of a 
toilet.

Or that Bernard Herrmann's musical score consists entirely of stringed 
instruments.

Or that director Alfred Hitchcock was so impressed with the 1955 French 
fright film Diabolique, directed by Henri Georges Clouzot, that he resolved 
to make a picture even more terrifying. I would argue he succeeded -- 
though just barely.

Or consider this (possibly apocryphal) story: an irritated viewer wrote 
Hitchcock to say that his daughter, after seeing Diabolique, would no 
longer take a bath and that after viewing Psycho she refused to shower as 
well. Hitchcock's reply?

"Send her to the dry cleaners."

Psycho remains a masterpiece of misdirection, audience manipulation and 
macabre humor. It's also on the very short list of scariest films I have 
seen, and I have seen a few. For that rare first-time viewer who has no 
clue what's coming, Psycho is gut-wrenching. Only Jaws and Silence of the 
Lambs come close.

Anyway, Hitchcock's cameo occurs about six minutes into the film. He's 
standing outside a real estate office, improbably wearing a cowboy hat.

We All Go a Little Mad Sometimes - Psycho (3/12) Movie CLIP (1960) HD﻿

However,  I saw the Psycho movie  for the second time in the last night.
But, still It was exciting for me.
Film was about a boy who had *Depersonalization disorder*.
This is the periods of detachment from self or surrounding which may be 
experienced as "unreal" (lacking in control of or "outside of" self) while 
retaining awareness that this is only a feeling and not a reality.

comments.author: Krume jovanovski

comments.text:
I cannot possibly pick a favourite, but have a soft spot for Marnie. Have 
seen Rebecca several times, love it more each time; Mrs Danvers is the best 
;-) I love the anecdotes too eg.Hitchcock had Joan Fontaine on verge of 
nervous breakdown in order to achieve a more authentic performance. I think 
it worked; her anxiety is palpable. But his quirks are all forgiven as far 
as I’m concerned because he was a genius. His v.early films are extremely 
good and  interesting, too. I so enjoy your music, Krume and thanks so much 
for sharing it. Have a lovely weekend! :-)
comments.author: Barbara Lendaro

comments.author: Mystic Pizza

comments.text:
They did a re-boot, in 1998, with Vince Vaughn as Norman, Anne Heche as 
Marion, Julianne Moore as Lila, Viggo Mortensen as Sam and William H. Macy 
as Arbogast.  It was a flop, and most people hate it, but I've always found 
it interesting.  Although I like Vince Vaughn, he was really the wrong 
choice for the role of Norman.  Hitchcock's Norman (Perkins) was small and 
skinny, and not much of a threat.  Vaughn is tall and stout, so right off 
the bat, you're like, "Wow, Mrs. Bates is like 6-foot-2."

comments.text:
I wonder who would have played the fat alcoholic Norman if they had done an 
adaptation of the book. At least the Texas Chainsaw Massacre,NOES and 
Friday the 13th remakes actually did a new version of the stories of the 
originals instead of just copying the original films scene for scene and 
shot for shot. Gus Van Sant wasted his time and money making a film which 
had already been made 38 years before.
comments.author: Xehanort10

comments.text:
I entirely agree. A shot-for-shot remake was really unnecessary, but an 
adaptation that was actually faithful to the source material would have 
been interesting. Not sure if it would have been better than Hitchcock's 
classic, but it sure would have been better than was Gus Van Sant ended up 
doing.
comments.author: EVILW0LFgirl

comments.text:
They should have used the novel's version of Norman in the 1998 remake 
instead of just making it a shot for shot color version of the 1960 film. 
Norman would have become Mother by getting drunk and passing out. Adapting 
the novel would have been a better idea than copying a film that had 
already been made.
comments.author: Xehanort10
